summary:
A 45-minute, 75-mark Maths paper that mixes quick-fire arithmetic (including negatives and order of operations) with standard KS2-to-early-KS3 topics: factors/primes, algebra basics, angles, fractions/percentages, data handling, and area/perimeter (including circles with π specified). Questions are mostly short-answer with marks shown per part and occasional brief explanation prompts. 

Hampton-Court-House-11-Plus-Mat…

topicWeighting.topic: arithmetic fluency (integers/decimals, order of operations, long multiplication/division)
fractions and mixed numbers (improper fractions, add/subtract, simplify)
number properties (primes, prime factors, smallest with given prime-factor conditions)
algebra basics (collecting like terms, simple linear equations)
sequences and patterns (extend pattern; first term below a threshold)
geometry: angles (missing angles on straight line/around a point)
geometry: area and perimeter (triangle, composite rectilinear shapes)
circles and shaded area (π given; circle in square)
statistics (mean/median/mode/range; effect of changing one value)
tables, probability, and proportional reasoning in context

formatRules:
Header instructions emphasise: 45 minutes, 75 marks, no calculators, show workings clearly, method credit may be awarded, and students should attempt as many questions as possible (not all candidates will finish). 

Hampton-Court-House-11-Plus-Mat…
Marks are shown in brackets per part (e.g., [1], [2], [3], [4]); generators should assign small mark values to quick items and higher marks to multi-step items.

Starts with a rapid set of 10 one-mark arithmetic questions that can be done mentally or with minimal working; include order-of-operations and a couple of negative-number operations in this starter set.
Include at least one explicit long multiplication (3-digit by 2-digit) requiring full working for method marks.

Sequence question style: provide the first several terms of a decreasing/increasing arithmetic pattern, then ask for (i) identifying properties from the list (even/prime/square), (ii) the next terms, and (iii) the first term below a stated bound (e.g., below zero).

Fractions/percent questions are straightforward contextual interpretation (fraction of animals, percentage of a total) and later procedural fraction skills (mixed number to improper; add/subtract fractions in simplest form).
Number theory appears as prime factorisation of a given integer and a ‘smallest number with four different prime factors’ style question; keep wording direct.
Algebra is early-KS3 level: simplify an expression by collecting like terms (x and y terms) and solve simple linear equations (including one involving a fraction coefficient such as x/2 + 3 = 12).

Angle questions use simple line/point diagrams; wording is just “Calculate the missing angles” with diagrams not necessarily labelled ‘not to scale’ in text, so the generator should rely on standard angle facts rather than measurement.

Include at least one timetable-reading task: a small table of departure/arrival times across stations, then ask for a travel time in minutes and a decision question (“which train should she take?”) requiring a short reason.

Include a two-way table completion problem (boys/girls by class) followed by fraction and probability questions, plus a final adjustment scenario (new pupils join; recompute counts given a condition like ‘half are now boys’).

Statistics question bundle uses an explicit list of scores and asks for range, median, mean, mode, then a short explanation comparing how a change affects mean but not median; keep explanation requirement concise.
Rounding is explicit and varied: nearest thousand (for a money division result) and significant figures (e.g., 2 s.f.). Generators should only include rounding/s.f. when stated in the question text.

Geometry measurement includes: (a) triangle perimeter and area with given height; (b) composite rectilinear shape requiring both area and perimeter; (c) circle area with π fixed (3.14) and an inscribed circle in a square asking for shaded area.
UNKNOWN: whether any topics like coordinates, simultaneous equations, or advanced reasoning puzzles appear in other HCH papers; this blueprint reflects the single uploaded specimen only.
maths.difficultyNotes: Overall moderate, with a broad KS2-to-early-KS3 coverage and a clear expectation of method marks. The challenge comes mainly from time pressure, accuracy (especially negatives, order of operations, and fraction simplification), and multi-step applied questions (timetables, tables/probability, statistics explanation, and geometry area/perimeter including circle-in-square).

formatRules: UNKNOWN: no English paper text was provided for this school; do not infer passage style, question stems, or writing tasks until English papers are supplied.
english.difficultyNotes: UNKNOWN: English difficulty cannot be inferred without English papers.

commonWrongAnswers: Order of operations mistakes (e.g., adding before multiplying).
Sign errors with negatives (especially subtracting negatives and dividing by a negative).
Arithmetic slips under time pressure in the quick starter section.
Incomplete working or missing method steps that would otherwise earn credit.
Prime factorisation errors (missing a repeated prime; stopping too early; not using index notation when appropriate).
Fraction errors: failing to convert mixed numbers correctly, incorrect common denominators, not simplifying final answers.
Mean/median confusion and weak explanation of why changing one value shifts mean but not median position.
Timetable misreads (mixing rows/columns, subtracting times incorrectly, choosing a train that arrives too late).
Probability errors from not using the correct conditional group (e.g., ‘chosen from class 6B’).
Geometry errors: perimeter tracing mistakes on composite shapes; area formula misuse; forgetting units (cm vs cm²).
Rounding/s.f. mistakes (rounding the wrong intermediate value; incorrect place value for ‘nearest thousand’).
Circle-in-square shaded area mistakes (using diameter as radius; forgetting to subtract circle area from square area).
markingAndFeedback.explanationTone: Clear and reassuring: show the minimal correct method, highlight the common trap in one sentence (especially signs, order of operations, and fraction simplification), and end with a quick check (substitute back, estimate, or unit check).

generatorHints: Do NOT copy any original questions.
Match the flavour, not the exact content.
Avoid references to printing or PDFs.
Keep questions suitable for an online timed exam.
Keep the paper calculator-free and method-mark friendly: require working for multi-mark parts and allow partial credit steps.
Include a short initial arithmetic section with many one-mark items, then move into mixed-topic multi-part questions.
Use straightforward, school-like contexts (animals, classes, timetables, test scores, jackpot sharing) rather than contrived puzzle narratives.
When using π, explicitly state the value to use (e.g., π = 3.14) and keep numbers clean enough for timed calculation.
Only include rounding/significant figures when explicitly requested in the question stem.
